column3: The path to the left led back to his father's cottage-the way of escape lay open.

column2: Once more, Magdalen looked round--looked with her resistless beauty, with her all-conquering smile.

column2: So, with a trifling gesture of invitation on one side, with a trifling act of compliance on the other: so--with no knowledge in his mind, with no thought in hers, of the secret still hidden under the journey to London--they took the way which led to that secret's discovery, through many a darker winding that was yet to come.

column2: VANSTONE'S inquiries into the proposed theatrical entertainment at Evergreen Lodge were answered by a narrative of dramatic disasters; of which Miss Marrable impersonated the innocent cause, and in which her father and mother played the parts of chief victims.
column3: VANSTONE'S inquiries into the proposed theatrical entertainment at Evergreen Lodge were answered by a narrative of dramatic disasters; of which Miss Marrable impersonated the innocent cause, and in which her father and mother played the parts of chief victims.

column2: Miss Marrable was that hardest of all born tyrants--an only child.
column3: Miss Marrable was that hardest of all born tyrants-an only child.

column2: She had never granted a constitutional privilege to her oppressed father and mother since the time when she cut her first tooth.
column3: She had never granted a constitutional privilege to her oppressed father and mother since the time when she cut her first tooth.

column2: Her seventeenth birthday was now near at hand; she had decided on celebrating it by acting a play; had issued her orders accordingly; and had been obeyed by her docile parents as implicitly as usual.
column3: Her seventeenth birthday was now near at hand; she had decided on celebrating it by acting a play; had issued her orders accordingly; and had been obeyed by her docile parents as implicitly as usual.

column2: Mrs. Marrable gave up the drawing-room to be laid waste for a stage and a theater.
column3: mrs Marrable gave up the drawing room to be laid waste for a stage and a theater.

column2: Mr. Marrable secured the services of a respectable professional person to drill the young ladies and gentlemen, and to accept all the other responsibilities incidental to creating a dramatic world out of a domestic chaos.
column3: mr Marrable secured the services of a respectable professional person to drill the young ladies and gentlemen, and to accept all the other responsibilities incidental to creating a dramatic world out of a domestic chaos.

column2: Having further accustomed themselves to the breaking of furniture and the staining of walls--to thumping, tumbling, hammering, and screaming; to doors always banging, and to footsteps perpetually running up and down stairs--the nominal master and mistress of the house fondly believed that their chief troubles were over.
column3: Having further accustomed themselves to the breaking of furniture and the staining of walls-to thumping, tumbling, hammering, and screaming; to doors always banging, and to footsteps perpetually running up and down stairs-the nominal master and mistress of the house fondly believed that their chief troubles were over.

column2: Innocent and fatal delusion!
column3: Innocent and fatal delusion!

column2: It is one thing in private society to set up the stage and choose the play--it is another thing altogether to find the actors.
column3: It is one thing in private society to set up the stage and choose the play-it is another thing altogether to find the actors.

column2: Hitherto, only the small preliminary annoyances proper to the occasion had shown themselves at Evergreen Lodge.
column3: Hitherto, only the small preliminary annoyances proper to the occasion had shown themselves at Evergreen Lodge.

column2: The sound and serious troubles were all to come.
column3: The sound and serious troubles were all to come.

column2: The Rivals having been chosen as the play, Miss Marrable, as a matter of course, appropriated to herself the part of "Lydia Languish." One of her favored swains next secured "Captain Absolute," and another laid violent hands on "Sir Lucius O'Trigger." These two were followed by an accommodating spinster relative, who accepted the heavy dramatic responsibility of "Mrs. Malaprop"--and there the theatrical proceedings came to a pause.
column3: The Rivals having been chosen as the play, Miss Marrable, as a matter of course, appropriated to herself the part of "Lydia Languish." One of her favored swains next secured "Captain Absolute," and another laid violent hands on "Sir Lucius O'Trigger." These two were followed by an accommodating spinster relative, who accepted the heavy dramatic responsibility of "mrs Malaprop"--and there the theatrical proceedings came to a pause.

column2: Nine more speaking characters were left to be fitted with representatives; and with that unavoidable necessity the serious troubles began.
column3: Nine more speaking characters were left to be fitted with representatives; and with that unavoidable necessity the serious troubles began.

column2: All the friends of the family suddenly became unreliable people, for the first time in their lives.
column3: All the friends of the family suddenly became unreliable people, for the first time in their lives.

column2: After encouraging the idea of the play, they declined the personal sacrifice of acting in it--or, they accepted characters, and then broke down in the effort to study them--or they volunteered to take the parts which they knew were already engaged, and declined the parts which were waiting to be acted--or they were afflicted with weak constitutions, and mischievously fell ill when they were wanted at rehearsal--or they had Puritan relatives in the background, and, after slipping into their parts cheerfully at the week's beginning, oozed out of them penitently, under serious family pressure, at the week's end.
column3: After encouraging the idea of the play, they declined the personal sacrifice of acting in it-or, they accepted characters, and then broke down in the effort to study them-or they volunteered to take the parts which they knew were already engaged, and declined the parts which were waiting to be acted-or they were afflicted with weak constitutions, and mischievously fell ill when they were wanted at rehearsal-or they had Puritan relatives in the background, and, after slipping into their parts cheerfully at the week's beginning, oozed out of them penitently, under serious family pressure, at the week's end.

column2: Meanwhile, the carpenters hammered and the scenes rose.
column3: Meanwhile, the carpenters hammered and the scenes rose.

column2: Miss Marrable, whose temperament was sensitive, became hysterical under the strain of perpetual anxiety; the family doctor declined to answer for the nervous consequences if something was not done.
column3: Miss Marrable, whose temperament was sensitive, became hysterical under the strain of perpetual anxiety; the family doctor declined to answer for the nervous consequences if something was not done.

column2: Renewed efforts were made in every direction.
column3: Renewed efforts were made in every direction.

column2: Actors and actresses were sought with a desperate disregard of all considerations of personal fitness.
column3: Actors and actresses were sought with a desperate disregard of all considerations of personal fitness.

column2: Necessity, which knows no law, either in the drama or out of it, accepted a lad of eighteen as the representative of "Sir Anthony Absolute"; the stage-manager undertaking to supply the necessary wrinkles from the illimitable resources of theatrical art.
column3: Necessity, which knows no law, either in the drama or out of it, accepted a lad of eighteen as the representative of "Sir Anthony Absolute"; the stage manager undertaking to supply the necessary wrinkles from the illimitable resources of theatrical art.

column2: A lady whose age was unknown, and whose personal appearance was stout--but whose heart was in the right place--volunteered to act the part of the sentimental "Julia," and brought with her the dramatic qualification of habitually wearing a wig in private life.
column3: A lady whose age was unknown, and whose personal appearance was stout-but whose heart was in the right place-volunteered to act the part of the sentimental "Julia," and brought with her the dramatic qualification of habitually wearing a wig in private life.

column2: Thanks to these vigorous measures, the play was at last supplied with representatives--always excepting the two unmanageable characters of "Lucy" the waiting-maid, and "Falkland," Julia's jealous lover.
column3: Thanks to these vigorous measures, the play was at last supplied with representatives-always excepting the two unmanageable characters of "Lucy" the waiting maid, and "Falkland," Julia's jealous lover.

column2: Gentlemen came; saw Julia at rehearsal; observed her stoutness and her wig; omitted to notice that her heart was in the right place; quailed at the prospect, apologized, and retired.
column3: Gentlemen came; saw Julia at rehearsal; observed her stoutness and her wig; omitted to notice that her heart was in the right place; quailed at the prospect, apologized, and retired.

column2: Ladies read the part of "Lucy"; remarked that she appeared to great advantage in the first half of the play, and faded out of it altogether in the latter half; objected to pass from the notice of the audience in that manner, when all the rest had a chance of distinguishing themselves to the end; shut up the book, apologized, and retired.

column2: I see nothing to laugh at--you would all be serious enough if you had my responsibilities.
column3: I see nothing to laugh at-you would all be serious enough if you had my responsibilities.

column2: No, papa--no wine to-day, thank you.
column3: No, papa-no wine to day, thank you.

column2: I must keep my intelligence clear.
column3: I must keep my intelligence clear.

column2: Water, Thomas--and a little more jelly, I think, before you take it away."
column3: Water, Thomas-and a little more jelly, I think, before you take it away."

column2: When Frank presented himself in the evening, ignorant of the first elements of his part, she took him in hand, as a middle-aged schoolmistress might have taken in hand a backward little boy.
column3: When Frank presented himself in the evening, ignorant of the first elements of his part, she took him in hand, as a middle aged schoolmistress might have taken in hand a backward little boy.

column2: The few attempts he made to vary the sternly practical nature of the evening's occupation by slipping in compliments sidelong she put away from her with the contemptuous self-possession of a woman of twice her age.
column3: The few attempts he made to vary the sternly practical nature of the evening's occupation by slipping in compliments sidelong she put away from her with the contemptuous self possession of a woman of twice her age.

column2: She literally forced him into his part.
column3: She literally forced him into his part.

column2: Her father fell asleep in his chair. Mrs. Vanstone and Miss Garth lost their interest in the proceedings, retired to the further end of the room, and spoke together in whispers. It grew later and later; and still Magdalen never flinched from her task--still, with equal perseverance, Norah, who had been on the watch all through the evening, kept on the watch to the end.
column3: Her father fell asleep in his chair. mrs Vanstone and Miss Garth lost their interest in the proceedings, retired to the further end of the room, and spoke together in whispers. It grew later and later; and still Magdalen never flinched from her task-still, with equal perseverance, Norah, who had been on the watch all through the evening, kept on the watch to the end.

column2: The distrust darkened and darkened on her face as she looked at her sister and Frank; as she saw how close they sat together, devoted to the same interest and working to the same end.
column3: The distrust darkened and darkened on her face as she looked at her sister and Frank; as she saw how close they sat together, devoted to the same interest and working to the same end.

column2: The clock on the mantel-piece pointed to half-past eleven before Lucy the resolute permitted Falkland the helpless to shut up his task-book for the night.
column3: The clock on the mantel piece pointed to half past eleven before Lucy the resolute permitted Falkland the helpless to shut up his task book for the night.

column2: She's wonderfully clever, isn't she? said Frank, taking leave of Mr. Vanstone at the hall door.
column3: She's wonderfully clever, isn't she? said Frank, taking leave of mr Vanstone at the hall door.

column2: I'm to come to-morrow, and hear more of her views--if you have no objection.	I'm to come to morrow, and hear more of her views-if you have no objection.
column3: true

column2: I shall never do it; don't tell her I said so.
column3: I shall never do it; don't tell her I said so.

column2: As fast as she teaches me one speech, the other goes out of my head.
column3: As fast as she teaches me one speech, the other goes out of my head.

column2: Discouraging, isn't it?
column3: Discouraging, isn't it?

column2: Goodnight."
column3: Goodnight."

column2: The next day but one was the day of the first full rehearsal.
column3: The next day but one was the day of the first full rehearsal.

column2: On the previous evening Mrs. Vanstone's spirits had been sadly depressed.
column3: On the previous evening mrs Vanstone's spirits had been sadly depressed.

column2: At a private interview with Miss Garth she had referred again, of her own accord, to the subject of her letter from London--had spoken self-reproachfully of her weakness in admitting Captain Wragge's impudent claim to a family connection with her--and had then reverted to the state of her health and to the doubtful prospect that awaited her in the coming summer in a tone of despondency which it was very distressing to hear.
column3: At a private interview with Miss Garth she had referred again, of her own accord, to the subject of her letter from London-had spoken self reproachfully of her weakness in admitting Captain Wragge's impudent claim to a family connection with her-and had then reverted to the state of her health and to the doubtful prospect that awaited her in the coming summer in a tone of despondency which it was very distressing to hear.

column2: Anxious to cheer her spirits, Miss Garth had changed the conversation as soon as possible--had referred to the approaching theatrical performance--and had relieved Mrs. Vanstone's mind of all anxiety in that direction, by announcing her intention of accompanying Magdalen to each rehearsal, and of not losing sight of her until she was safely back again in her father's house.
column3: Anxious to cheer her spirits, Miss Garth had changed the conversation as soon as possible-had referred to the approaching theatrical performance-and had relieved mrs Vanstone's mind of all anxiety in that direction, by announcing her intention of accompanying Magdalen to each rehearsal, and of not losing sight of her until she was safely back again in her father's house.

column2: Accordingly, when Frank presented himself at Combe-Raven on the eventful morning, there stood Miss Garth, prepared--in the interpolated character of Argus--to accompany Lucy and Falkland to the scene of trial.
column3: Accordingly, when Frank presented himself at Combe Raven on the eventful morning, there stood Miss Garth, prepared-in the interpolated character of Argus-to accompany Lucy and Falkland to the scene of trial.

column2: The railway conveyed the three, in excellent time, to Evergreen Lodge; and at one o'clock the rehearsal began.
column3: The railway conveyed the three, in excellent time, to Evergreen Lodge; and at one o'clock the rehearsal began.
